deliberation: The verse addresses Zion/Israel as a barren, desolate woman who will have more children than a married wife. This is not describing an individual woman but the community; thus the whole motherhood/barrenness scene is an extended metaphor of national restoration, grounded in marital/fertility imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: רׇנִּ֥י עֲקָרָ֖ה לֹ֣א יָלָ֑דָה ... כִּֽי־רַבִּ֧ים בְּֽנֵי־שׁוֹמֵמָ֛ה מִבְּנֵ֥י בְעוּלָ֖ה
instances.english_text: Shout, O infertile one, you who bore no child! … For the children of the wife forlorn shall outnumber those of the espoused.
vehicle: a barren, desolate wife who later has more children than a married woman
marital and maternal figure
family/marriage and fertility domain
ground: transition from barrenness to extraordinary fruitfulness and from shame to honor
reversal of fortunes and dramatic increase of dependents/children
restoration and expansion after exile
posture: God exhorting Zion to rejoice despite present ‘barrenness’ because of promised future offspring
comforting and honor-restoring proclamation
prophetic reassurance of national restoration
instances.explanation: The barren, forlorn woman who becomes more fruitful than a married wife images Zion, currently depopulated and shamed, yet destined to have more ‘children’ (inhabitants) than before.

deliberation: The verse commands the addressee to enlarge a tent with curtains, ropes, and pegs. In the context of communal restoration, these domestic/nomadic building instructions function metaphorically for making room for a greatly enlarged population and sphere.

instances.hebrew_text: הַרְחִ֣יבִי מְק֣וֹם אׇהֳלֵ֗ךְ ... הַאֲרִ֙יכִי֙ מֵיתָרַ֔יִךְ וִיתֵדֹתַ֖יִךְ חַזֵּֽקִי
instances.english_text: Enlarge the site of your tent … Lengthen the ropes, and drive the pegs firm.
vehicle: a nomadic tent being enlarged with extended curtains, ropes, and firm pegs
domestic dwelling structure
pastoral/nomadic living domain
ground: making more room to accommodate greater numbers
growth, stability, and preparation for expansion
blessing and increased population after exile
posture: imperative to prepare concretely for coming increase
confident anticipatory instruction
prophetic assurance of imminent enlargement
instances.explanation: The commands to enlarge the tent signify Zion’s need to prepare for a coming influx of inhabitants and blessings; the physical tent imagery stands for corporate expansion and stability.

deliberation: The verse speaks of spreading out to the right and left and of offspring inheriting nations and inhabiting desolate cities. The key figurative element is the image of ‘bursting out’ right and left, a spatial metaphor (with a meristic pair) for total expansion.

instances.english_text: For you shall spread out to the right and the left
vehicle: something bursting forth to the right and to the left
lateral overflow in all directions
spatial expansion domain
ground: unrestrained, multidirectional increase
breaking previous bounds and occupying more space
full-scale restoration and extension
posture: promissory depiction of comprehensive expansion
assuring portrayal of future success
prophetic vision of total enlargement
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘to the right and to the left you will burst out’ uses a meristic pair (right/left) and the verb ‘burst forth’ to picture Zion’s complete and vigorous expansion in all directions.

deliberation: The verse recalls ‘the reproach of your youth’ and ‘the shame of your widowhood.’ These are not literal biographical stages of a single woman but extended marriage imagery applied to Zion’s past humiliations, continuing the wife metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֣י בֹ֤שֶׁת עֲלוּמַ֙יִךְ֙ תִּשְׁכָּ֔חִי וְחֶרְפַּ֥ת אַלְמְנוּתַ֖יִךְ לֹ֥א תִזְכְּרִי־עֽוֹד
instances.english_text: For you shall forget the reproach of your youth, and remember no more the shame of your widowhood.
target: Zion/Israel’s earlier periods of disgrace and loss (e.g., exile, national crisis)
vehicle: a woman’s disgrace in early married life and the shame of being a widow
marital and social status of a wife/bride/widow
family and social honor domain
ground: humiliation, vulnerability, and social stigma associated with youthful dishonor and widowhood
painful memory that can be put away and not recalled
transition from dishonor to restored dignity
posture: reassuring that prior humiliations will be erased
comfort that shifts focus from shame to future honor
prophetic consolation about God’s renewed favor
instances.explanation: Zion’s past national disgrace is portrayed as the reproach of a young wife and the shame of a widow, highlighting vulnerability and loss that God promises will no longer dominate her identity.

deliberation: Here God is explicitly called the ‘husband’ of the addressee and her ‘redeemer.’ This is a central marital metaphor: YHWH’s covenant relationship to Zion/Israel is likened to a husband’s role toward his wife.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י בֹעֲלַ֙יִךְ֙ עֹשַׂ֔יִךְ יְהֹוָ֥ה צְבָא֖וֹת שְׁמ֑וֹ וְגֹֽאֲלֵךְ֙ קְד֣וֹשׁ יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל
instances.english_text: For the One who made you … will espouse you. The Holy One of Israel … will redeem you.
vehicle: a husband (בּוֹעֵל) who espouses and a kinsman-redeemer
marital and family-legal roles
marriage and kinship domain
ground: exclusive commitment, protection, provision, and right of redemption
intimacy and obligation inherent in a husband–wife bond
faithful, personal, and binding relationship
posture: affirming and dignifying Zion’s status as divinely ‘married’
comforting by stressing God’s personal commitment
covenantal reassurance of enduring bond
instances.explanation: By calling Himself Zion’s ‘husband’ and ‘redeemer,’ God depicts His covenant with her in terms of a faithful spouse who both loves and legally protects, thereby elevating her from abandonment to honored marital status.

deliberation: The main figure is an explicit simile: YHWH has called Zion ‘like a forsaken and grieved wife,’ and the question about casting off the wife of one’s youth reinforces the marriage imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּֽי־כְאִשָּׁ֧ה עֲזוּבָ֛ה וַעֲצ֥וּבַת ר֖וּחַ קְרָאָ֣ךְ יְהֹוָ֑ה וְאֵ֧שֶׁת נְעוּרִ֛ים כִּ֥י תִמָּאֵ֖ס
instances.english_text: For the LORD has called you back as a wife forlorn and forsaken, and as a wife of youth who is cast off.
target: covenant people under judgment and then recall
vehicle: a forsaken wife, grieved in spirit, a wife of youth who has been rejected
marital relationship in crisis
family/marriage domain
ground: deep emotional pain, sense of rejection, and longing for reconciliation
social and emotional vulnerability of a cast-off wife
experience of being abandoned yet still desired for restoration
posture: empathetic comparison to highlight Zion’s pain while announcing recall
tender yet corrective assurance that rejection is not final
prophetic consolation framed in familiar family terms
instances.explanation: Zion’s situation is likened to that of a forsaken, heartbroken wife of one’s youth, emphasizing the depth of her sorrow and the surprising graciousness of God’s call to take her back.

deliberation: Exile and restoration are depicted in marital and gathering language: ‘I forsook you for a brief moment’ and ‘with great mercies I will gather you.’ The brevity of the ‘moment’ is rhetorically compressed, and the gathering image is metaphorical for regathering the people.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּרֶ֥גַע קָטֹ֖ן עֲזַבְתִּ֑יךְ וּבְרַחֲמִ֥ים גְּדֹלִ֖ים אֲקַבְּצֵֽךְ
instances.english_text: For a little while I forsook you, but with vast love I will bring you back.
target: the duration and severity of Zion’s exile and subsequent restoration
historical experience of judgment and mercy
vehicle: a brief, momentary forsaking followed by a great, gathering embrace
temporal contrast of ‘small moment’ vs. ‘great mercies’ and the act of physically gathering someone back
family/marriage and spatial-gathering domain
ground: judgment as relatively brief compared to the magnitude of mercy
restoration pictured as re-gathering a separated beloved
emphasis on disproportionate, overwhelming compassion
posture: minimizing the exile in comparison to future mercy to comfort the hearer
assuring that abandonment was temporary and restoration abundant
prophetic encouragement stressing God’s generous disposition
instances.explanation: The ‘little moment’ of forsaking versus the ‘great mercies’ of gathering uses compressed temporal hyperbole and gathering imagery to show that God’s restorative compassion vastly outweighs the period of judgment.

deliberation: The key figure is the idiomatic expression ‘I hid my face from you,’ an anthropomorphic metaphor for withdrawing favor or presence; it is contrasted with ‘everlasting kindness.’

instances.hebrew_text: בְּשֶׁ֣צֶף קֶ֗צֶף הִסְתַּ֨רְתִּי פָנַ֥י רֶ֙גַע֙ מִמֵּ֔ךְ
instances.english_text: In slight anger, for a moment, I hid My face from you
target: God’s relational stance toward Zion during judgment
vehicle: a person turning or hiding his face in anger from another
facial orientation as a sign of relational favor or displeasure
human interpersonal/embodied interaction
ground: withdrawing attention and favor resembles turning one’s face away
relational distance and displeasure signaled by hiding the face
sense of abandonment or lack of access
posture: explaining past judgment in relational, humanly intelligible terms
mitigating severity by stressing its brevity and smallness
preparing for the contrast with everlasting kindness
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘I hid my face’ is an idiomatic anthropomorphic metaphor: God’s withdrawal of favor is pictured as someone literally turning away or concealing his face from another person.

deliberation: The verse explicitly compares the present promise to the ‘waters of Noah.’ This is a simile invoking the flood narrative as an analogy for the irrevocability of God’s new oath toward Zion.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּֽי־מֵ֥י נֹ֙חַ֙ זֹ֣את לִ֔י ... כֵּ֥ן נִשְׁבַּ֛עְתִּי מִקְּצֹ֥ף עָלַ֖יִךְ
instances.english_text: For this to Me is like the waters of Noah … So I swear that I will not be angry with you or rebuke you.
target: God’s present commitment not to be angry with Zion again in the same way
the durability of His post-exilic promise
vehicle: the waters of Noah and the oath never again to flood the earth
primeval judgment and subsequent irreversible covenant
primeval history/cosmic judgment domain
ground: both involve a divine oath never to repeat a catastrophic judgment
sense of finality and permanence of God’s promise
assurance grounded in remembered, paradigmatic divine faithfulness
posture: strengthening trust by analogy to a well-known, foundational promise
arguing from past divine reliability to present assurance
didactic reassurance through historical comparison
instances.explanation: By saying the present situation is ‘like the waters of Noah,’ God likens His promise to refrain from wrath toward Zion to His ancient oath never again to flood the earth, stressing comparable irrevocability.

deliberation: God contrasts the hypothetical moving of mountains and shaking of hills with the unshakable nature of His kindness and covenant. The imagery of cosmic instability functions as a hyperbolic metaphor to stress the greater stability of divine loyalty.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י הֶהָרִים֙ יָמ֔וּשׁוּ וְהַגְּבָע֖וֹת תְּמוּטֶ֑ינָה וְחַסְדִּ֞י מֵאִתֵּ֣ךְ לֹא־יָמ֗וּשׁ וּבְרִ֤ית שְׁלוֹמִי֙ לֹ֣א תָמ֔וּט
instances.english_text: For the mountains may move and the hills be shaken, but My loyalty shall never move from you, nor My covenant of friendship be shaken.
target: the permanence of God’s kindness and covenant with Zion
vehicle: mountains departing and hills being shaken versus something that cannot be moved
cosmic and geological instability contrasted with steadfastness
nature/cosmic order domain
ground: mountains and hills normally symbolize the most stable features of creation
even if such stable things were to collapse, God’s covenant would still remain
emphasis on surpassing reliability and unchangeableness
posture: using vivid, almost unimaginable change to magnify divine steadfastness
reassuring the hearer by an ‘even if’ hyperbolic scenario
pastoral strengthening of trust in God’s unshaken loyalty
instances.explanation: The idea that mountains might move and hills shake is a hyperbolic image of cosmic upheaval, used to say that even in such an extreme scenario God’s loyal love and covenant with Zion would remain immovable.

deliberation: Zion is described as ‘poor, storm-tossed, uncomforted’ and then promised foundations of precious stones. The first clause is a metaphor of emotional and social distress; the second shifts to architectural gemstone imagery to portray glorious rebuilding.

target: Zion/Israel in her afflicted, exilic state
vehicle: a poor, storm-tossed, uncomforted woman or entity
one battered by a tempest with no comfort
weather/sea-storm and social vulnerability domain
ground: instability, disorientation, and exposure to destructive forces
lack of comfort, security, and resources
experience of ongoing turmoil without relief
posture: recognizing and empathizing with the depth of Zion’s distress
setting up a stark contrast to the promised restoration
compassionate address to a wounded community
instances.explanation: Calling Zion ‘poor, storm-tossed, uncomforted’ pictures her as like someone caught in a violent storm and left in misery, capturing the chaos and vulnerability of her exilic condition.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּ֨ה אָנֹכִ֜י מַרְבִּ֤יץ בַּפּוּךְ֙ אֲבָנַ֔יִךְ וִֽיסַדְתִּ֖יךְ בַּסַּפִּירִֽים
instances.english_text: I will lay your stones with carbuncle (antimony) and make your foundations of sapphires.
target: Zion’s future condition and structure as a restored community/city
status, beauty, and security of the people
vehicle: a building whose stones and foundations are made of or set with precious gems
lavishly adorned architecture
construction/ornamentation domain
ground: precious stones connote beauty, value, and permanence
solid foundations signify security and stability
public, visible splendor replacing prior ruin
posture: promising extravagant, beautifying restoration
reversing earlier image of poverty into one of opulence
encouraging hope through luxurious architectural imagery
instances.explanation: The depiction of Zion’s stones and foundations as precious gems symbolizes a transformed community marked by glory, value, and enduring stability, in sharp contrast to her storm-tossed poverty.

deliberation: This verse continues the gemstone-building imagery: battlements, gates, and borders made of precious stones. It figuratively represents the community’s future glory, security, and desirability.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשַׂמְתִּ֤י כַּֽדְכֹד֙ שִׁמְשֹׁתַ֔יִךְ וּשְׁעָרַ֖יִךְ לְאַבְנֵ֣י אֶקְדָּ֑ח וְכׇל־גְּבוּלֵ֖ךְ לְאַבְנֵי־חֵֽפֶץ
instances.english_text: I will make your battlements of rubies, your gates of precious stones, the whole encircling wall of gems.
target: the character and status of restored Zion/Jerusalem
vehicle: battlements, gates, and borders constructed from costly gems
city fortifications made of ornamental precious stones
urban architecture and luxury materials domain
ground: gems signify exceptional value, beauty, and distinction
fortifications and gates represent protection and controlled access
a city famed for its splendor and secure boundaries
posture: depicting the restoration in maximally attractive, honor-laden terms
assuring both beauty and safety for the future community
prophetic exaltation of Zion’s coming glory
instances.explanation: The description of walls and gates as made of precious stones is a metaphor imaging Zion’s future as both secure and dazzlingly glorious, not a literal blueprint but a symbolic portrayal of exalted status.

deliberation: The verse promises that all the children will be taught by YHWH and have great peace. While divine instruction can be mediated, the language here is straightforwardly promissory and does not overtly rely on a distinct figurative vehicle.

Two main figures appear: being ‘established through righteousness’ uses construction imagery for moral/spiritual foundation, and ‘ruin not coming near you’ personifies ruin/terror as an approaching agent.

instances.english_text: You shall be established through righteousness.
target: Zion’s stability and secure standing as a community
social and spiritual order of the restored people
vehicle: a structure being founded or firmly established on a base
architectural foundation imagery
building/construction domain
ground: a sound foundation supports and stabilizes a building
righteousness (just conduct/relationship) provides security and durability for a community
rightness of order corresponds to structural firmness
posture: linking moral/spiritual integrity to communal stability
instructing and assuring by using concrete building imagery
didactic encouragement toward righteousness as basis for safety
instances.explanation: Righteousness is portrayed as the foundation on which Zion is firmly set, like a building on a solid base, suggesting that just order undergirds lasting security.

instances.english_text: And from ruin, for it shall not come near you.
target: the threat of disaster or terror against Zion
experiences of harm to the community
vehicle: ruin or terror imagined as something that can draw near or stay far away
an approaching hostile agent
movement/approach in personal confrontation domain
ground: dangers that ‘come near’ are those that affect and harm a person or city
keeping an enemy at a distance means safety
proximity as a metaphor for effective impact
posture: comforting by depicting ruin as unable to approach
reassuring with the image of danger kept at bay
pastoral depiction of divine protection in personal terms
instances.explanation: ‘Ruin’ is personified as though it could come near or stay away; its inability to approach Zion pictures the community as safely beyond the reach of destructive forces.

deliberation: The verse speaks of those who ‘gather’ or ‘attack’ against Zion and then ‘fall’ because of her. The falling language is a common battle idiom for defeat, functioning as a conventional metaphor.

instances.english_text: Whoever would harm you shall fall because of you.
target: the fate of those who oppose Zion
vehicle: falling down in battle or conflict
bodily collapse as a sign of defeat
warfare/combat domain
ground: those who are defeated typically fall or are made to fall
falling signals loss of power and vulnerability
physical collapse equates to being overcome
posture: promising that opponents will be defeated
reassuring Zion by portraying enemies as collapsing before her
prophetic guarantee of divinely backed victory
instances.explanation: The statement that those who contend with Zion ‘shall fall’ uses the physical image of falling in combat as a metaphor for suffering defeat at her hands.

deliberation: The verse asserts that God created the smith who forges weapons and also the destroyer to ruin. Although this sets theological context for the next verse, the language itself is largely literal, describing craftsman and destroyer without a distinct figurative vehicle.
The statement about weapons not succeeding is mostly literal in context, but ‘every tongue that contends with you’ uses ‘tongue’ metonymically for hostile speech or its speaker in legal conflict.

instances.english_text: And every tongue that contends with you at law you shall defeat.
target: those who bring accusations or hostile arguments against God’s servants
adversarial witnesses or accusers in legal/forensic settings
opponents in judicial and rhetorical arenas
vehicle: the ‘tongue’ of a person
organ of speech standing for speaking person or their words
body-part and speech domain
ground: speech is produced by the tongue, so it can represent the speaker or their utterances
the core of legal contention lies in spoken charges and arguments
focusing on the tongue highlights the verbal nature of opposition
posture: assuring that verbal and legal attacks will be overturned
empowering the servants of YHWH by promising forensic vindication
legal-rhetorical reassurance of divine backing
instances.explanation: ‘Every tongue that contends with you’ uses ‘tongue’ as a metonymy for the accuser or their hostile speech in court; the promise is that such accusing voices will be condemned and silenced.
